instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: When were the system sizing adjustments added?
output: These system sizing adjustments were added as of version 8.9 of EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What is the basic idea behind the system sizing adjustments?
output: The basic idea is to account for operating details of the air terminal units attached to the system by making adjustments to the system sizing results after the zone equipment has been setup and sized.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What does the routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments do?
output: The routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments has been added that first sets up the zone equipment and then makes adjustments to the system sizing by mining information from the air terminal models for minimum flow fractions operating modes during heating and any user-defined hard sizes to improve accuracy and robustness.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: How do the actual operating flow rates during heating compare to the design heating flow rate?
output: Once the air terminals are setup the actual operating flow rates during heating are often quite different from the design heating flow rate derived from the zone loads.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What does the adjustment method do regarding air terminals?
output: The adjustment method scans all the air terminals and develops accurate values for the minimum and maximum flow rates that will occur during heating operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What happens to the system design heating flow rate after adjustment?
output: The system design heating flow rate is adjusted to reflect the new result from scanning the air terminals.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: How is the heating design flow rate determined in a VAV system with Normal action dampers?
output: In a VAV system with Normal action dampers that is cooling dominated the heating design flow rate is the cooling design flow rate times the minimum flow fraction at the dampers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What adjustment is made when heating loads dominate?
output: When heating loads dominate the cooling design flow rate needs to be adjusted to account for how the terminals will really operate during cooling rather than the cooling-load-based sizing result.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What does the routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments adjust?
output: The routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments adjusts system sizing outcomes based on how the zone air terminals finish out their sizing.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: How are the zone models executed?
output: The zone models are executed to trigger their sizing routines by calling ManageZoneEquipment().

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What does the routine do for each airloop?
output: For each airloop the routine loops over all the zones attached to that air loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What is summed for every air terminal connected to a particular air loop?
output: Every air terminal connected to a particular air loop is summed for minimum flow rate during heating operation maximum flow rate during heating operation and maximum flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: What zone level flow information is stored for Standard 62.1 calculations?
output: The routine stores zone level flow information for Standard 62.1 calculations Vpz Vpzmin Vdz and Vdzmin for both cooling and heating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Sizing Adjustments for Air Terminal Operation -> text
input: Where are the three summed values for terminal air flows reported?
output: The three summed values for terminal air flows for each airloop are reported to the EIO and table summary report using the outputs 'Sum of Air Terminal Maximum Heating Flow Rates [m3/s]' 'Sum of Air Terminal Minimum Heating Flow Rates [m3/s]' and 'Sum of Air Terminal Maximum Flow Rates [m3/s].'

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How do actual operating flow rates during heating compare to the design heating flow rate derived from zone loads?
output: The actual operating flow rates during heating are often quite different from the design heating flow rate derived from the zone loads.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the adjustment method do with air terminals?
output: The adjustment method scans all the air terminals and develops accurate values for the minimum and maximum flow rates that will occur during heating operation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the system design heating flow rate adjusted?
output: The system design heating flow rate is adjusted to reflect the new result from the adjustment method.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: In a VAV system with Normal action dampers that is cooling dominated what is the relationship between the heating design flow rate and the zone loads?
output: In a VAV system with Normal action dampers that is cooling dominated the heating design flow rate is no longer really related to the zone loads but is the cooling design flow rate times the minimum flow fraction at the dampers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What needs to be adjusted when heating loads dominate?
output: When heating loads dominate the cooling design flow rate needs to be adjusted to account for how the terminals will really operate during cooling rather than the cooling-load-based sizing result.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments do?
output: The routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments adjusts system sizing outcomes based on how the zone air terminals finish out their sizing.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How are the zone models executed?
output: The zone models are executed to trigger their sizing routines by calling ManageZoneEquipment().

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the routine do for each airloop?
output: For each airloop the routine loops over all the zones attached to that air loop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is summed for every air terminal connected to a particular air loop?
output: Every air terminal connected to a particular air loop is summed for: (1) minimum flow rate during heating operation (airLoopHeatingMinimumFlowRateSum) (2) maximum flow rate during heating operation (airLoopHeatingMaximumFlowRateSum) and (3) maximum flow rate (airLoopMaxFlowRateSum).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What zone level flow information does the routine store for Standard 62.1 calculations?
output: The routine stores zone level flow information for Standard 62.1 calculations \emphVpz \emphVpzmin \emphVdz and \emphVdzmin for both cooling and heating.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Where are the three summed values for terminal air flows for each airloop reported?
output: The three summed values for terminal air flows for each airloop are reported to the EIO and table summary report using the outputs 'Sum of Air Terminal Maximum Heating Flow Rates [m3/s]' 'Sum of Air Terminal Minimum Heating Flow Rates [m3/s]' and 'Sum of Air Terminal Maximum Flow Rates [m3/s].'

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How are the summed values used in system sizing results?
output: The summed values are used to 'Adjust' the system sizing results in specific ways.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the possible settings for the type of zone sum to use?
output: The setting for the type of zone sum to use can be either \emphnoncoincident or \emphcoincident.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: In the \emphnoncoincident approach how is the design system heating flow rate set?
output: In the \emphnoncoincident approach the design system heating flow rate is set to be the larger of the airloop heating maximum flow rate sum (from the air terminals) and the design flow rate from the load based calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the design system main flow rate set?
output: The design system main flow rate is set to be the larger of the airloop maximum flow rate sum (from the air terminals) and the design flow rate from the larger of the cooling and heating calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling design flow rate set for a \emphnoncoincident and \textbfcooling dominant air loop?
output: For \emphnoncoincident and \textbfcooling dominant the cooling design air flow rate is set to the design main air flow (typically the airLoopMaxFlowRateSum).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling design air flow rate set for \emphcoincident and \textbfheating dominant air loops?
output: For \emphcoincident and \textbfheating dominant the cooling design air flow rate is set to the larger of the original cooling-load-based value for flow and the lowest value the air handler will really operate at (from the airLoopHeatingMinimumFlowRateSum).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Why is the air terminal summation not as useful for \emphcoincident type sums?
output: For \emphcoincident type sums the air terminal summation is not as useful because we generally expect that the straight sum of air terminal sizes will be larger than the coincident sum because by its very nature the straight sum is only expected to match noncoincident approach.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the purpose of adjustments for \emphcoincident type sums?
output: The adjustments are more to keep design flows within bounds set by minimum and maximum sums so that the coincident sum is within physical bounds set by how the air terminals can operate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: For \emphcoincident and \textbfcooling dominant airloops how is the heating design flow rate determined?
output: For \emphcoincident and \textbfcooling dominant airloops (a) the heating design flow rate is the larger of the heating minimum flow rate (from the airLoopHeatingMinimumFlowRateSum) and the design heat flow from the coincident design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What check is performed on the main design flow for \emphcoincident and \textbfcooling dominant airloops?
output: For \emphcoincident and \textbfcooling dominant airloops the main design flow is not typically altered but it will be checked to be at least as large as the heating minimum flow.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the types of zone sums that can be used?
output: The setting for the type of zone sum to use can be either noncoincident or coincident.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the design system heating flow rate determined for noncoincident zone sums?
output: For noncoincident the design system heating flow rate is set to be the larger of the airloop heating maximum flow rate sum and the design flow rate from the load based calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the design system main flow rate determined?
output: The design system main flow rate is set to be the larger of the airloop maximum flow rate sum and the design flow rate from the larger of the cooling and heating calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling design flow rate set for a noncoincident and cooling dominant air loop?
output: For noncoincident and cooling dominant the cooling design air flow rate is set to the design main air flow.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling design air flow rate set for coincident and heating dominant zone sums?
output: For coincident and heating dominant the cooling design air flow rate is set to the larger of the original cooling-load-based value for flow and the lowest value the air handler will really operate at.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Why is the air terminal summation not as useful for coincident type sums?
output: The air terminal summation is not as useful because we generally expect that the straight sum of air terminal sizes will be larger than the coincident sum.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the heating design flow rate for coincident and cooling dominant airloops?
output: For coincident and cooling dominant airloops the heating design flow rate is the larger of the heating minimum flow rate and the design heat flow from the coincident design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the main design flow rate checked for coincident and cooling dominant airloops?
output: The main design flow is not typically altered but it will be checked to be at least as large as the heating minimum flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling design flow rate set for coincident and cooling dominant airloops?
output: The cooling design flow rate is set to the main design flow which we expect to be the result of the coincident design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the heating design flow rate for coincident and heating dominant airloops?
output: For coincident and heating dominant airloops the heating design flow rate is the larger of the heating maximum flow rate and the design heat flow rate from the coincident design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the main design flow rate set for coincident and heating dominant airloops?
output: The main design flow rate is set to be the larger of the heating maximum flow rate and main design flow rate from the coincident sizing calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling design flow rate set for coincident and heating dominant airloops?
output: The cooling design flow rate is set to be the larger of the heating minimum flow rate and the cooling design flow rate from the coincident calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Where are the adjusted system sizes for each airloop reported?
output: The resulting adjusted system sizes for each airloop are reported to the EIO and table summary report.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What outputs are used to report the adjusted system sizes?
output: The outputs 'Adjusted Heating Design Air Flow Rate [m3/s]' 'Adjusted Cooling Design Air Flow Rate [m3/s]' and 'Adjusted Main Design Air Flow Rate [m3/s]' are used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: What does the routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments include?
output: The routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments includes calculating the ratio for the central heating maximum system air flow rate to the maximum flow rate for the airloop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: What is the input field called for the central heating maximum system air flow ratio?
output: This ratio is the input field called Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio in the Sizing:System object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: Can the central heating maximum system air flow ratio be autosized?
output: As of version 8.9 the central heating maximum system air flow ratio can be autosized.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: Why is the value calculated even if the input was not autosized?
output: The value is calculated so that inputs can be checked.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: How is the central heating flow ratio autosized?
output: The corrected values are used to autosize the central heating flow ratio if set to autosize by the user.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: How is the central heating maximum system air flow ratio calculated?
output: The ratio is calculated by dividing the adjusted design heating flow by the adjusted design main flow.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: Can the design outdoor air flow rate input in the Sizing:System object be autosized?
output: The design outdoor air flow rate input in the Sizing:System object can be set to autosize.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the cooling design flow rate set to for coincident and heating dominant airloops?
output: The cooling design flow rate is set to the main design flow which is expected to be the result of the coincident design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the heating design flow rate determined for coincident and heating dominant airloops?
output: The heating design flow rate is the larger of the heating maximum flow rate (from the airLoopHeatingMaximumFlowRateSum) and the design heat flow rate from the coincident design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the main design flow rate set for coincident and heating dominant airloops?
output: The main design flow rate is set to be the larger of the heating maximum flow rate (from the airLoopHeatingMaximumFlowRateSum) and main design flow rate from the coincident sizing calculations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling design flow rate set for coincident and heating dominant airloops?
output: The cooling design flow rate is set to be the larger of the heating minimum flow rate (from the airLoopHeatingMinimumFlowRateSum) and the cooling design flow rate from the coincident calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Where are the resulting adjusted system sizes for each airloop reported?
output: The resulting adjusted system sizes for each airloop are reported to the EIO and table summary report using the outputs 'Adjusted Heating Design Air Flow Rate [m3/s]' 'Adjusted Cooling Design Air Flow Rate [m3/s]' and 'Adjusted Main Design Air Flow Rate [m3/s].'

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: What does the routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments calculate?
output: The routine ManageSystemSizingAdjustments calculates the ratio for the central heating maximum system air flow rate to the maximum flow rate for the airloop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: What is the Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio in the Sizing:System object?
output: The Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio is an input field in the Sizing:System object and as of version 8.9 can be autosized.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: Why is the Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio calculated even if the input was not autosized?
output: The value is calculated even if the input was not autosized so that inputs can be checked.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Central Heating Maximum System Air Flow Ratio Sizing -> text
input: How is the ratio for the central heating maximum system air flow rate calculated?
output: The ratio is calculated by dividing the adjusted design heating flow by the adjusted design main flow.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: Can the design outdoor air flow rate input in the Sizing:System object be set to autosize?
output: Yes the design outdoor air flow rate input in the Sizing:System object can be set to autosize.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: What do the sizing calculations for determining the system-level design outdoor air flow rate depend on?
output: The sizing calculations depend on the method chosen in the field called System Output Air Method in Sizing:System either ZoneSum Standard62.1VentilationRateProcedure or Standard62.1SimplifiedProcedure and the design results at the zone level.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: Which standard does the system-level design outdoor air flow rate calculation follow?
output: The calculations generally follow the Standard 62.1 approach.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: How are the Standard 62.1 calculations applied in the sizing calculations?
output: The Standard 62.1 calculations are applied separately for both peak cooling design conditions and peak heating design conditions and the larger is taken to be the single design outdoor air volume flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: What does the predefined table summary report 'Standard 62.1 Summary' provide?
output: The report provides a comprehensive summary of the calculations for outdoor air rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: What are the system level summations and flow rate results based on as of version 8.9?
output: They are based on the adjusted system sizes and zone level summations that mine the individual air terminals attached to the air handlers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Outdoor Air Flow Rate -> text
input: What concludes the system design calculation?
output: The sentence 'This concludes the system design calculation.' marks the end of the system design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Scalable System HVAC Sizing -> text
input: What does the scalable system sizing apply to?
output: The scalable system sizing applies to system supply air flow rates and system capacity in cooling and heating modes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Scalable System HVAC Sizing -> text
input: What are the scalable sizing methods for supply air flow rate?
output: The scalable sizing methods for supply air flow rate are FlowPerFloorArea FractionOfAutosizedCoolingAirflow or FlowPerCoolingCapacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Scalable System HVAC Sizing -> text
input: How is the cooling supply air volume flow rate calculated using FlowPerFloorArea?
output: The cooling supply air volume flow rate is calculated from zone floor area served by the airloop and user specified Flow Per Floor Area value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Scalable System HVAC Sizing -> text
input: How is the cooling supply air volume flow rate calculated using FractionOfAutosizedCoolingAirflow?
output: The cooling supply air volume flow rate is calculated from user specified fraction and the autosized design cooling supply air volume flow rate value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What do calculations for determining the system-level design outdoor air flow rate depend on?
output: Calculations for determining the system-level design outdoor air flow rate Vot depend on the method chosen in the field called System Output Air Method in Sizing:System either ZoneSum Standard62.1VentilationRateProcedure or Standard62.1SimplifiedProcedure and the design results at the zone level.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What approach do the calculations generally follow?
output: The calculations generally follow the Standard 62.1 approach and are discussed separately in the Demand Controlled Ventilation section elsewhere in the Engineering Reference.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How are the Standard 62.1 calculations applied in the sizing calculations?
output: The sizing calculations apply the Standard 62.1 calculations separately for both peak cooling design conditions and peak heating design conditions and take the larger to be the single design outdoor air volume flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the predefined table summary report 'Standard 62.1 Summary' provide?
output: The predefined table summary report 'Standard 62.1 Summary' provides a comprehensive summary of the calculations for outdoor air rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: As of version 8.9 what are the system level summations and flow rate results based on?
output: As of version 8.9 the system level summations and flow rate results are based on the adjusted system sizes and zone level summations that mine the individual air terminals attached to the air handlers.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What concludes the system design calculation?
output: This concludes the system design calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does scalable system sizing apply to?
output: The scalable system sizing applies to system supply air flow rates and system capacity in cooling and heating modes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the scalable sizing methods for supply air flow rate?
output: The scalable sizing methods for supply air flow rate allowed are either FlowPerFloorArea FractionOfAutosizedCoolingAirflow or FlowPerCoolingCapacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling supply air volume flow rate calculated using the FlowPerFloorArea method?
output: FlowPerFloorArea means the program calculates the cooling supply air volume flow rate from zone floor area served by the airloop and user specified Flow Per Floor Area value.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the cooling supply air volume flow rate calculated using the FractionOfAutosizedCoolingAirflow method?
output: FractionOfAutosizedCoolingAirflow means the program calculates the cooling supply air volume flow rate from user specified fraction and the autosized design cooling supply air volume flow rate value determined by the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the heating supply air volume flow rate calculated using the FractionOfAutosizedHeatingAirflow method?
output: FractionOfAutosizedHeatingAirflow means the program calculates the heating supply air volume flow rate from user specified fraction and the autosized design heating supply air volume flow rate value determined by the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the supply air volume calculated using the FlowPerCoolingCapacity method?
output: FlowPerCoolingCapacity means the supply air volume is calculated from user specified flow per cooling capacity and design cooling capacity determined by the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the supply air volume calculated using the FlowPerHeatingCapacity method?
output: FlowPerHeatingCapacity means the supply air volume is calculated from user specified flow per heating capacity and design heating capacity determined by the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the scalable sizing methods for system capacity?
output: The scalable sizing methods for system capacity available are: CapacityPerFloorArea FractionOfAutosizedCoolingCapacity and FractionOfAutosizedHeatingCapacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the design capacity calculated using the CapacityPerFloorArea method?
output: CapacityPerFloorArea means the program calculates the design capacity from user specified capacity per floor area and floor area of the zones served by the airloop.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the design cooling capacity calculated using the FractionOfAutosizedCoolingCapacity method?
output: FractionOfAutosizedCoolingCapacity means the program calculates the design cooling capacity from user specified fraction and the auto-sized design cooling capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: System Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the design heating capacity calculated using the FractionOfAutosizedHeatingCapacity method?
output: FractionOfAutosizedHeatingCapacity means the program calculates the design heating capacity from user specified fraction and the auto-sized design heating capacity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the challenge in establishing design HVAC flow rates and sizing HVAC equipment?
output: There is no single best way to establish design HVAC flow rates and size HVAC equipment. Different building designs climates and HVAC systems will impose varying constraints on the designer.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How does the method of sizing an HVAC system differ between climates?
output: The method used to size an HVAC system in a hot moist climate such as Miami will be different than the method used for a building in Albuquerque.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Why might a simple watts per square foot loads estimate be adequate for some buildings?
output: A simple watts per square foot loads estimate could be adequate for a building containing a network server farm.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What type of building requires a detailed dynamic loads simulation?
output: A detailed dynamic loads simulation would be necessary for a passive solar building.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What role does the designer's experience and engineering judgment play in sizing calculations?
output: In the end the designer's experience and engineering judgment will play an important role in any sizing calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the starting point for HVAC equipment sizing?
output: HVAC equipment sizing begins with the calculation of space heating and cooling sensible and/or latent loads.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is a space cooling (heating) sensible load defined?
output: A space cooling (heating) sensible load is defined as the rate at which heat must be removed (added) to a space to maintain a constant zone temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is a space cooling (heating) latent load defined?
output: A space cooling (heating) latent load is defined as the rate at which moisture must be removed (added) to a space to maintain a constant zone moisture/humidity ratio/relative humidity level.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the current industry standard method for calculating space loads?
output: The current industry standard method for calculating space loads is the heat balance method.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Why is it straightforward for EnergyPlus to use the heat balance method for calculating zone loads?
output: Since EnergyPlus is a heat balance based simulation program it is straightforward for the program to use this method for calculating zone loads.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> Section: Zone Design Data Arrays -> text
input: What does the ZoneSizingInput(i) array store?
output: ZoneSizingInput(i) stores the input data from the Sizing:Zone objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> Section: Zone Design Data Arrays -> text
input: What does the CalcZoneSizing(ij) array store?
output: CalcZoneSizing(ij) stores the results of the zone design calculations for all zones and all design days. The index i is for the controlled zones j for design days.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> Section: Zone Design Data Arrays -> text
input: What does the CalcFinalZoneSizing(i) array store?
output: CalcFinalZoneSizing(i) stores the results of the zone design calculations for the peak heating and cooling cases for each zone. The index i is for the controlled zones.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> Section: Zone Design Data Arrays -> text
input: What does the ZoneSizing(ij) array correspond to?
output: ZoneSizing(ij) corresponds to CalcZoneSizing but includes the effect of the user specified sizing factor or user specified zone design flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> Section: Zone Design Data Arrays -> text
input: What does the FinalZoneSizing(i) array correspond to?
output: FinalZoneSizing(i) corresponds to CalcFinalZoneSizing but includes the effect of the user specified sizing factor or user specified zone design flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> Section: Zone Design Data Arrays -> text
input: What does the TermUnitFinalZoneSizing(k) array correspond to?
output: TermUnitFinalZoneSizing(k) corresponds to FinalZoneSizing but includes the effect of any air system terminal unit sizing factors input with DesignSpecification:AirTerminal:Sizing objects. The index k is for each air terminal unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> Section: Zone Design Data Arrays -> text
input: Is the number of terminal units always the same as the number of controlled zones?
output: There may be more or less terminal units than there are controlled zones.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> table: Zone Sizing Data
input: What information is stored in the ZoneSizingInput?
output: Select data from ZoneSizingInput.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> table: Zone Sizing Data
input: What is DesHeatMassFlow?
output: DesHeatMassFlow is the zone design sensible heating air mass flow rate in [kg/s].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> table: Zone Sizing Data

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the Sizing Manager do during the zone design load calculation?
output: The Sizing Manager initiates the zone design calculation by looping over all of the design days and calling the Heat Balance Manager for each zone time-step in each design day.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What role does the Heat Balance Manager play in the zone design load calculation?
output: The Heat Balance manager causes the HVAC Manager to be called in a manner identical to a normal simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens when ZoneSizingCalc is set to true?
output: When ZoneSizingCalc is set to true the HVAC Manager ignores the actual HVAC system and instead calculates the design sensible and latent zone loads and air flow rates using an ideal zonal system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the ManageHVAC subroutine do in the HVACManager module?
output: In the HVACManager module the ManageHVAC subroutine calls SimHVAC.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does SimHVAC do if ZoneSizingCalc is true?
output: If ZoneSizingCalc is true SimHVAC calls ManageZoneEquipment and returns rather than simulating the actual system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the Sizing Manager do to initiate the zone design calculation?
output: The Sizing Manager initiates the zone design calculation by looping over all of the design days and calling the Heat Balance Manager for each zone time-step in each design day.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the Heat Balance manager cause during the zone design calculation?
output: The Heat Balance manager causes the HVAC Manager to be called in a manner identical to a normal simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does setting ZoneSizingCalc to true signal the HVAC Manager to do?
output: Setting ZoneSizingCalc to true signals the HVAC Manager to ignore the actual HVAC system and instead calculate the design sensible and latent zone loads and air flow rates using an ideal zonal system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does SimHVAC do if ZoneSizingCalc is true?
output: If ZoneSizingCalc is true SimHVAC calls ManageZoneEquipment and returns rather than simulating the actual system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does ManageZoneEquipment do if ZoneSizingCalc is true?
output: If ZoneSizingCalc is true ManageZoneEquipment calls SizeZoneEquipment rather than SimZoneEquipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What assumption does SizeZoneEquipment make about each controlled zone?
output: SizeZoneEquipment assumes that each controlled zone is served by an ideal air conditioning unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the characteristics of the ideal air conditioning unit assumed by SizeZoneEquipment?
output: The unit supplies sensible and latent (if latent sizing is requested) heating or cooling air at a fixed user input temperature and humidity (specified in the Sizing:Zone objects) and has infinite capacity with any flow rate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens to zone humidity when latent sizing is requested?
output: Zone humidity is controlled at a constant level when latent sizing is requested.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Where are the sensible and latent loads and air mass flow rates saved and reported?
output: The sensible and latent loads and air mass flow rates are saved and reported to eplusout.zsz.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the function check before calculating the ideal zone load?
output: Before calculating the ideal zone load the function checks whether the user wants to account for the heat gain or loss caused by the ventilation air from a Dedicated Outdoor Air System (DOAS).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens if the user selects 'Account For Dedicated Outdoor Air = Yes'?
output: If the user selects 'Account For Dedicated Outdoor Air = Yes' the function performs an ideal DOAS calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the three possible control strategies for the DOAS supply temperature?
output: The three possible control strategies for the DOAS supply temperature are NeutralSupplyAir NeutralDehumidifiedSupplyAir or ColdSupplyAir.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the purpose of the DOAS Control Strategy = NeutralSupplyAir?
output: The purpose of this strategy is to cool or heat the outdoor air (OA) to keep it between the T_l and T_h setpoints.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the purpose of the DOAS Control Strategy = Neutral Dehumidified Supply Air?
output: The purpose is to cool and dehumidify the outdoor air then reheat it to a 'neutral' temperature so that no sensible load is imposed on the space or AHU unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens if the outdoor air temperature is greater than T_l in the Neutral Dehumidified Supply Air strategy?
output: If the outdoor air temperature is greater than T_l the outdoor air is cooled to T_l and reheated to T_h.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens if ZoneSizingCalc is true?
output: If ZoneSizingCalc is true it calls SizeZoneEquipment rather than SimZoneEquipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What assumption does SizeZoneEquipment make about controlled zones?
output: SizeZoneEquipment assumes that each controlled zone is served by an ideal air conditioning unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the ideal air conditioning unit supply?
output: This unit supplies sensible and latent (if latent sizing is requested) heating or cooling air at a fixed user input temperature and humidity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the capacity of the units in the ideal air conditioning model?
output: The units have infinite capacity: the flow rate can be any amount.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens to zone humidity when latent sizing is not requested?
output: When latent sizing is not requested zone humidity is allowed to float.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Where are the sensible and latent loads and air mass flow rates reported?
output: The sensible and latent loads and air mass flow rates are saved and reported to eplusout.zsz.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the function check before calculating the ideal zone load?
output: The function checks whether the user wants to account for the heat gain or loss caused by the ventilation air from a Dedicated Outdoor Air System (DOAS).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens if the user selects 'Account For Dedicated Outdoor Air = Yes'?
output: If the user has selected 'Account For Dedicated Outdoor Air = Yes' the function performs an ideal DOAS calculation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the three possible DOAS control strategies?
output: The DOAS supply temperature is set according to the user's choice of one of three possible control strategies: NeutralSupplyAir NeutralDehumidifiedSupplyAir or ColdSupplyAir.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: Where is the DOAS supply temperature value reported?
output: This value is saved and reported to eplusout.zsz.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the purpose of the 'DOAS Control Strategy = NeutralSupplyAir'?
output: The purpose of this strategy is to cool or heat the outdoor air (OA) to keep it between the T_l and T_h setpoints.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What does the 'DOAS Control Strategy = Neutral Dehumidified Supply Air' aim to achieve?
output: The purpose of this strategy is to cool and dehumidify the outdoor air then reheat it to a 'neutral' temperature so that no sensible load is imposed on the space or AHU unit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How does the DOAS handle the latent load under the 'Neutral Dehumidified Supply Air' strategy?
output: The DOAS will handle some or all of the latent load with this strategy.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens to the outdoor air temperature if it is greater than T_l in the 'Neutral Dehumidified Supply Air' strategy?
output: If the outdoor air temperature is greater than T_l the outdoor air is cooled to T_l and reheated to T_h.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens to the outdoor air temperature if it is below T_l in the 'Neutral Dehumidified Supply Air' strategy?
output: If the outdoor air temperature is below T_l it is heated to T_h.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the purpose of the 'DOAS Control Strategy = ColdSupplyAir'?
output: The purpose of this strategy is to provide cool dehumidified ventilation air to the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What can the DOAS handle in the 'ColdSupplyAir' strategy?
output: In this case the DOAS can handle part of the sensible zone cooling load as well as meet part or all of the latent load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens to the outdoor air temperature if it is below T_l in the 'ColdSupplyAir' strategy?
output: If the outdoor air temperature is below T_l it is heated to T_h.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens to the outdoor air temperature if it is above T_l in the 'ColdSupplyAir' strategy?
output: If it is above T_l it is cooled to T_l.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat addition rate with the DOAS supply temperature set?
output: \\dot Q_doa = c_pair\\dot m_ventmin(T_sup - T_z)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is invoked to adjust the load to be met by the ideal zone system?
output: UpdateSystemOutputRequired is then invoked to adjust the load to be met by the ideal zone system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens when latent sizing is requested?
output: When latent sizing is requested the sensible and latent loads provided by the DOAS are updated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the units for the latent load?
output: Latent load units are kgw per second.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> equation
input: What is the equation for the latent load provided by the DOAS?
output: \\dot Q_doa moisture = \\dot m_ventmin(w_sup - w_z)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What are the steps in the ideal loads calculation?
output: The ideal loads calculation steps are as follows: 1) Loop over all the controlled zones. 2) If the system is active (zone temperature not in the deadband and zone load greater than 1 watt) the sign of the zone load is used to determine whether heating or cooling is required and T_in and W_in are set to the appropriate values from the Sizing:Zone input.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens when the SupplyTemperature method is specified in the Sizing:Zone object?
output: When the SupplyTemperature method is specified in the Sizing:Zone object T_in is fixed at the cooling or heating supply temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens when the TemperatureDifference method is selected?
output: When the TemperatureDifference method is selected T_in is calculated at each time step using the current zone air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: How is the system output Q_sys set?
output: The system output Q_sys is simply set equal to the zone demand - it is assumed that the ideal system can always meet the zone load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> equation
input: What is the equation for the air flow rate corresponding to the load?
output: \\dot m_sys = Q_sys/(C_pair \\cdot

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What is the purpose of the DOAS Control Strategy when set to ColdSupplyAir?
output: The purpose of this strategy is to provide cool dehumidified ventilation air to the zone. In this case the DOAS can handle part of the sensible zone cooling load as well as meet part or all of the latent load.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> text
input: What happens if the outdoor air temperature is below T_l?
output: If the outdoor air temperature is below T_l it is heated to T_h.

input: What happens if the outdoor air temperature is above T_l?
output: If it is above T_l it is cooled to T_l.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Loop Equipment Sizing and other Design Data -> Section: Zone Design Loads and Air Flow Rates -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat addition rate with the DOAS supply temperature set?
output: \\dot Q_doa = c_pair\\dot m_ventmin(T_sup - T_z)
